title: 114_hr3720
content: The Act may be cited as the "Water Advanced Technologies for Efficient Resource Use Act of 2015". It includes a section on WaterSense. The WaterSense program, established within the Environmental Protection Agency, promotes water efficient products, buildings, and landscapes to reduce water use, strain on infrastructure, conserve energy, and preserve water resources for future generations through voluntary labeling. The Administrator of the EPA is responsible for promoting WaterSense labeled products, enhancing public awareness, and educating the public on water recycling. The WaterSense program promotes water-efficient technologies and services to reduce water use and ensure product performance. It aims to enhance public awareness, establish performance standards, publicize proper installation of WaterSense products, preserve the label's integrity, and regularly review criteria for labeled products. The WaterSense program aims to preserve the label's integrity by regularly reviewing and updating criteria for labeled products. It also collects data on market shares and estimates water and energy savings annually. Interested parties and the public are invited to provide feedback before establishing or revising any criteria. The WaterSense program ensures transparency and stakeholder involvement in updating criteria for labeled products. It requires providing notice of changes, explaining them, and considering lead time for effective dates to accommodate manufacturing and distribution processes. Authorization of Appropriations: $7,500,000 for fiscal year 2016, $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2017, $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2018, and $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2019 and beyond, adjusted for inflation, to support water efficiency initiatives in various sectors. Federal procurement of water efficient products is mandated. In this section, definitions are provided for terms such as "agency," "WaterSense product or service," "WaterSense program," "FEMP designated product," and "product and service." The terms exclude water consuming products for combat missions and those already covered by Federal procurement regulations. The terms in this section exclude water consuming products for combat missions and those already covered by Federal procurement regulations. Agencies are required to procure WaterSense products or FEMP designated products for water consuming products or services, with exceptions allowed. WaterSense plumbing products should be installed by certified professionals for optimal performance. The head of an agency may be exempt from procuring WaterSense or FEMP designated products if they find it not cost-effective or if no suitable products are available. Agencies must include specifications for water consuming products in all procurements. The head of an agency may consider additional measures to reduce water consumption, including water reuse, leak detection, and use of waterless products. WaterSense and FEMP designated products must be clearly identified in federal catalogs. The General Services Administration and the Defense Logistics Agency must supply WaterSense or FEMP designated products unless specified otherwise in writing. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will issue regulations within 180 days to implement this requirement. SEC. 4. EARLY ADOPTER WATER EFFICIENT PRODUCTS INCENTIVE PROGRAMS. The section defines key terms like "Administrator," "eligible entity," "incentive program," and "residential water efficient product or service" for the Early Adopter Water Efficient Products Incentive Programs. The section outlines criteria for residential water efficient products or services, which must be rated by the WaterSense program or an approved incentive program. Categories include faucets, irrigation technologies, water treatment devices, toilets, and showerheads. Products must undergo third-party certification to meet performance and efficiency requirements. The term "State" refers to various regions within the United States, including Puerto Rico and Guam. The "WaterSense program" is defined as a program established by a specific Act. Eligible entities can receive allocations if they have incentive programs for water-efficient products and services. The Administrator allocates funds to eligible entities for water-efficient products and services based on population served and target population of incentive programs. The allocated funds can cover up to 50% of the cost for implementing incentive programs targeting specific populations. Entities are encouraged to promote fixture recycling programs for older fixtures replaced through the program. Financial incentives can be issued to consumers who meet program requirements, either directly or with approval to delegate some incentives. Financial incentives may be provided to consumers who meet program requirements, with the entity having the option to delegate incentive administration to other organizations. The amount of the incentive is determined based on various factors, including the entity's allocation, available tax incentives, consumer behavior change, and consumer expenditures. $50,000,000 is authorized for the Administrator to carry out this section. Authorization of Appropriations.--$50,000,000 for fiscal year 2016, $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2017, $150,000,000 for fiscal year 2018, $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2019, and $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2020 are authorized for the Administrator to carry out consumer incentives program. SEC. 5. EARLY ADOPTER WATER EFFICIENT PRODUCTS INCENTIVE PROGRAMS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude income received under an incentive program for water-efficient products. No double benefit allowed for any expenditure covered by the program. The amendments made by this Act regarding early adopter water efficient products incentive programs will apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment date.
